what: Generate High Resolution Shade Maps and Shaded Routes from Remote Sensing Data
title: Generate High Resolution Shade Maps and Shaded Routes from Remote Sensing Data
text: CityShadeMapper open source R package generates high-resolution insolation shade maps remote sensing (LiDAR) data. Free LiDAR data now available many countries (e.g. Spain). Shade maps can generated every hour year every square meter entire cities (e.g. see https://www.mapasdesombra.org).

title: Generate High Resolution Shade Maps and Shaded Routes from Remote Sensing Data
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("Pakillo/CityShadeMapper")

title: Generate High Resolution Shade Maps and Shaded Routes from Remote Sensing Data
text: example using LiDAR data Sevilla, Spain (provided IGN):  See https://www.mapasdesombra.org developed application shade maps canopy ground level Sevilla city southern Spain.
code: library("CityShadeMapper")  # Read LiDAR data lidar <- read_lidar(system.file("extdata", "catedral.laz", package = "CityShadeMapper"))  # Calculate heights from LiDAR data heights <- calc_heights_from_lidar(lidar)  # Calculate shade maps for 30 April (all day) shade <- make_shademap(heights, date = "2022-04-30", hour = 8:21)  plot_shademap(shade, legend = FALSE, animate = TRUE, smooth = TRUE)

title: Generate High Resolution Shade Maps and Shaded Routes from Remote Sensing Data
text: CityShadeMapper builds upon wonderful open source packages (e.g. lidR, solartime, rayshader, terra, GDAL, etc) make possible. CityShadeMapper uses LiDAR point cloud build detailed height map city, including trees buildings. height information, knowing sun position every time year given geographic coordinates city, CityShadeMapper calculates amount solar rays hitting every pixel surface (either roof/canopy ground level).

title: Generate High Resolution Shade Maps and Shaded Routes from Remote Sensing Data
text: Shade intensity tree canopies currently fixed low (5% illumination) value. information available vegetation type, density, etc, used refine calculation shade intensities tree canopies, .e. ground level. Illumination calculations canopy/roof level unaffected .

text: height.mat Height matrix, calculated terra_to_matrix(). sun.altitude Sun altitude (angle horizon, degrees) sun.angle Sun angle degrees (zero degrees North, increasing clockwise) zscale Default 1. ratio x y spacing (assumed equal) z axis. example, elevation units meters grid values separated 10 meters, zscale 10. crs coordinate reference system, see terra::crs() extent raster extent, see terra::ext() filename Character. title: Calculate shades from elevation map — calc_shade
code: if (FALSE) { lidar.file <- system.file("extdata", "PlazaNueva.laz", package = "CityShadeMapper", mustWork = TRUE) lidar <- read_lidar(lidar.file) heights <- calc_heights_from_lidar(lidar) library(terra) height.mat <- CityShadeMapper:::terra_to_matrix(subset(heights, 1)) sun.pos <- get_sun_position(lon = -5.99567, lat = 37.38876, date = "2022-10-18", hour = 15) shaderas <- calc_shade(height.mat, sun.altitude = sun.pos$elevation, sun.angle = sun.pos$azimuth, crs = crs(heights), extent = ext(heights)) plot_shademap(shaderas) }

Either 'canopy' get illumination canopy/roof level, 'ground' get illumination ground level (.e. pedestrians). cover.ras SpatRaster containing cover classes (ground, vegetation, buildings...). See rasterize_lidar_cover_class(). zscale Default 1. ratio x y spacing (assumed equal) z axis. example, elevation units meters grid values separated 10 meters, zscale 10. omit.nights Logical. TRUE, sun positions returned daytime (.e. nighttimes omitted) filename Character. Output filename. Note file already exists name, overwritten. ... arguments rayshader::ray_shade()

code: if (FALSE) { lidar <- PlazaNueva() heights <- calc_heights_from_lidar(lidar) shaderas <- make_shademap(heights, date = "2022-10-15", hour = 13) plot_shademap(shaderas, smooth = TRUE) shaderas <- make_shademap(heights, date = "2022-10-15", hour = 8:20) plot_shademap(shaderas, animate = TRUE, smooth = TRUE) shaderas <- make_shademap(heights, date = "2022-07-15", hour = 8:21) plot_shademap(shaderas, animate = TRUE, smooth = TRUE) shaderas <- make_shademap(heights, date = c("2022-07-15", "2022-10-15"), hour = 13) plot_shademap(shaderas, legend = FALSE)  ## Ground-level shade maps require additional raster with cover classes lidar <- read_lidar(system.file("extdata", "PlazaNueva.laz", package = "CityShadeMapper")) cover.ras <- rasterize_lidar_cover_class(lidar) shaderas <- make_shademap(heights, date = "2022-10-15", hour = 13,   type = "ground", cover.ras = cover.ras)  }
